questions.text: What is the normal prostate volume in a healthy adult male? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in the correct sequence involved in the basal ganglia direct motor pathway: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence is as follows:

 

5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.

 

1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.

 

3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.

 

4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.

 

The basal ganglia needs the input from the cortex in order to act. The first and last component of the pathway is always the cerebral cortex. 


The complete pathway is Cortex/ Thalamus/ brain stem to stratum, then to globus pallidus & substantia nigra then to thalamus and then back to cortex.


Hence out of the available options 5,1,2,3,4 is the best suitable.

 

 

 

The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: Home based urine pregnancy tests detect which hormone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

Home-based urine pregnancy tests detect human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), specifically the beta subunit of hCG (β-hCG).

 

  • hCG is the earliest detectable hormone in pregnancy
  • hCG is secreted by the trophoblastic cells of the developing placenta soon after implantation, which occurs approximately 6-10 days post-fertilization.
  • The hormone helps maintain the corpus luteum, ensuring continued progesterone production to support early pregnancy.
  • Urine pregnancy tests typically detect hCG levels at or above 20-25 mIU/mL, allowing for early pregnancy confirmation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): This is a pituitary hormone involved in follicular development and not specific to pregnancy. It is not used for pregnancy detection as its levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle.

 

Option C. Estrogen: While estrogen levels do increase during pregnancy, it is not specific enough for pregnancy detection as it is also present during normal menstrual cycles.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Although progesterone levels rise during pregnancy, it is not used in home pregnancy tests as it is also present during the luteal phase of menstrual cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Home pregnancy tests specifically detect the beta subunit of hCG in urine for pregnancy diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Explanation:

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lithium: Lithium is not hepatotoxic. It primarily affects the kidneys (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus) and thyroid (causing hypothyroidism). Common side effects include tremor, weight gain, and cognitive dulling.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is associated with hematologic toxicities (like agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia), SIADH, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. It is not commonly hepatotoxic, although rare hepatic dysfunction has been reported.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Topiramate is not associated with liver toxicity. Side effects include weight loss, renal stones, paresthesias, cognitive slowing, and metabolic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked as 'A', is the hyoid bone, which is not a part of the laryngeal skeleton.

 

The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located at the base of the tongue. While it is not considered a part of the larynx itself.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A - Hyoid bone

B - Thyroid cartilage

C - Epiglottis

D - Cricoid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilage in the larynx. It forms the prominent Adam's apple in the front of the neck and plays a role in sound production.

 

Option C. Epiglottis: The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage  which belongs to larynx located at the base of the tongue. Its primary function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the airway (trachea) during swallowing.

 

Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is the only complete ring of cartilage in the larynx and provides structural support to the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A set of cartilages that are joined by ligaments and fibrous membranes make up the laryngeal skeleton:

 

  • Hyaline cartilage: The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages
  • Elastic cartilage: The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

The clinical presentation described suggests lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by filarial worms. Lymphatic filariasis commonly leads to lymphedema, especially of the extremities, due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels by the parasites. The characteristic finding of limb swelling that is more pronounced proximally than distally is typical for lymphatic involvement.

 

Night Blood Test for Worms: This is the appropriate diagnostic test as filarial worms are nocturnally periodic, meaning that the microfilariae (larval stage of the filarial worm) are present in peripheral blood predominantly during the night (between 10 pm and 4 am). This periodicity aligns with the feeding patterns of the mosquito vectors that transmit the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: This would typically be used to assess heart function and structure, especially relevant given her history of coronary artery disease, but it would not be useful for diagnosing conditions affecting the lymphatic system like filariasis.

 

Option C. Duplex venous scan of limbs: This test assesses venous circulation and could help rule out venous thrombosis or other venous insufficiencies but would not be the first choice when filariasis is suspected.

 

Option D. ECG: While important for monitoring heart conditions, an ECG would not provide information relevant to diagnosing or managing lymphatic swelling due to filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

choices.text: It moves against the concentration gradient

questions.text: Which statement is true about facilitated diffusion? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. It requires a carrier

 

Explanation:

 

Facilitated diffusion is a form of passive transport that requires specific carrier proteins to move substances across the cell membrane. These carrier proteins bind molecules and then change their configuration, facilitating the movement of the bound substance across the membrane. This type of transport is characterized by several key properties: it requires specific carrier proteins, exhibits saturation kinetics, shows specificity for the transported substance, and can demonstrate competition between similar molecules for the same carrier.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. It is active - False. Facilitated diffusion is classified as passive transport, not active transport. It moves substances down their concentration or electrical gradient without requiring energy input.
  • Option c. It requires ATP - False. Unlike primary active transport, facilitated diffusion does not require ATP or other energy sources. The movement occurs due to the existing concentration gradient.
  • Option d. It moves against the concentration gradient - False. Facilitated diffusion only moves substances down their concentration gradient (from high to low concentration), never against it. Moving substances against their concentration gradient requires active transport mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport process requiring specific carrier proteins (such as GLUT for glucose) that enables the movement of substances down their concentration gradient across cell membranes at a faster rate than would occur by simple diffusion alone.

questions.text: Which of the following types of joints is not formed by the bone shown in the image?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The image shows a thoracic vertebra, identifiable by its long spinous process, body, and superior and inferior articular facets. Thoracic vertebrae participate in forming several types of joints but do not form synchondroses. A synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage, which is not present in the thoracic vertebra.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: Incorrect. Syndesmosis joints are formed where two bones are connected by a ligament. An example related to the vertebrae would be the interspinous ligament connecting adjacent spinous processes.

 

Option C. Plane joint: Incorrect. Plane joints are formed by thoracic vertebrae, such as the costovertebral and costotransverse joints, where the ribs articulate with the thoracic vertebrae.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Incorrect. Symphysis joints are formed between the vertebral bodies of adjacent thoracic vertebrae via the intervertebral discs, which are composed of fibrocartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracic vertebrae do not form synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous) joints; they are involved in forming plane joints, syndesmosis, and symphysis joints.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.

questions.text: Which of the following acts by causing both decreased bone resorption and increased bone formation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strontium ranelate

 

Strontium ranelate is a unique agent used in the treatment of osteoporosis. It has a dual mode of action: it decreases bone resorption and simultaneously increases bone formation. This dual effect is beneficial in managing osteoporosis, as it helps to improve bone density and strength by promoting a balanced bone remodeling process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ibandronate: Ibandronate is a bisphosphonate that primarily acts by reducing bone resorption. It inhibits osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone turnover and increased bone mineral density.

 

Option C. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that primarily stimulates bone formation. It acts on osteoblasts, increasing their activity and promoting new bone formation.

 

Option D. Calcitonin: Calcitonin decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity. It is used in the treatment of conditions like osteoporosis and Paget's disease but does not significantly promote bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strontium ranelate is unique among osteoporosis treatments in that it both decreases bone resorption and increases bone formation, making it a valuable option for improving bone health in patients with osteoporosis. Other drugs like ibandronate and calcitonin primarily focus on reducing bone resorption, while teriparatide promotes bone formation.

questions.text: Which of the following regulates the body temperature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothalamus

 

Explanation:


The regulation of body temperature is primarily controlled by the hypothalamus. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for cooling mechanisms, akin to standing in front of an air conditioner during hot weather. Conversely, the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus manages warming mechanisms, similar to standing near an exhaust to receive warm air during cold weather.

This dual role in temperature regulation is unique to the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are involved in the coordination of movement and motor control, but they do not play a role in temperature regulation.

 

Option C. Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, and does not regulate body temperature.

 

Option D. Limbic system: The limbic system is involved in emotions, behavior, and long-term memory, but it does not have a role in the regulation of body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypothalamus, specifically its anterior and posterior nuclei, is responsible for regulating body temperature.

questions.text: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of which of the following drugs? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imipenem

 

Imipenem is a carbapenem that is broken down by the enzyme dehydropeptidase in the kidney. Cilastatin is therefore administered along with it, which is an inhibitor of dehydropeptidase, thereby it prolongs the action of Imipenem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meropenem: Meropenem is another carbapenem antibiotic, but it is not significantly degraded by renal dehydropeptidase I and does not require co-administration with cilastatin.

 

Option C. Cefazolin: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that is not affected by renal dehydropeptidase I and does not require cilastatin for its administration.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic, and its activity is not influenced by renal dehydropeptidase I, thus not requiring cilastatin for its administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cilastatin is specifically administered with imipenem to inhibit renal dehydropeptidase I, preventing the breakdown of imipenem and thereby prolonging its action in the body.

questions.text: Which is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium valproate

 

Sodium valproate is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea. It's an anticonvulsant medication that has proven effective in managing the involuntary movements associated with this condition. It works primarily by enhancing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which helps reduce abnormal electrical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a medication used primarily to treat gout by reducing the levels of uric acid in the blood. It is not used for the treatment of rheumatic chorea.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seizures. While it can provide muscle relaxation and sedation, it is not the drug of choice for managing refractory rheumatic chorea.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that can be used in some movement disorders. While it has been used in chorea, it is not considered the optimal treatment for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its side effect profile and efficacy compared to sodium valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred drug for treating refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its efficacy in reducing involuntary movements by enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain. It has a better side effect profile for long-term management of this condition compared to other options.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontotemporal dementia

 

Frontotemporal dementia, specifically the form associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (FTD-ALS complex), is caused by a hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9ORF72 gene. This expansion consists of GGGGCC (G4C2) repeats. It's one of the few known hexanucleotide repeat disorders and is a significant cause of both frontotemporal dementia and ALS.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fragile X Syndrome: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: Incorrect. There are two types of myotonic dystrophy. Type 1 is a trinucleotide (CTG) repeat disorder, while type 2 is a tetranucleotide (CCTG) repeat disorder.

 

Option D. Huntington disease: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CAG repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene, resulting in an expanded polyglutamine tract.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Stop the drug and proceed drug free

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder with previous history of 4 episodes and no episode for the past 1 year, well controlled with 750 mg Lithium, now in the third trimester , comes to the psychiatrist. What is the next step in management ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease dose

 

Lithium doses may need adjustment during pregnancy due to changes in renal clearance, especially in the third trimester, to minimize toxicity risks while maintaining therapeutic effects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose: Increasing the dose isn't recommended due to increased risk of lithium toxicity in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Switch to valproate: Switching to valproate is not advised due to its high teratogenic risk, especially for neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Stop the drug and proceed drug free: Stopping lithium abruptly can lead to a high risk of relapse in bipolar disorder; it's important to manage it carefully.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, it's crucial to carefully manage lithium dosage to balance efficacy with safety, avoiding both relapse and toxicity.

questions.text: The space between bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process is called: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hiatus Semilunaris

 

Explanation: 

 

The hiatus semilunaris is the gap between the bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process. It represents a two-dimensional space with a width of approximately 1-2mm. The uncinate process is a hook-like structure that runs from anterosuperior to posteroinferior direction, with its sharp posterosuperior border running parallel to the anterior border of the bulla ethmoidalis, creating this distinctive gap.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agger nasi :This is an elevation located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. When pneumatized, it contains agger nasi cells which may communicate with the frontal recess, but it is not the space between the bulla and uncinate process.

 

Option B. Olfactory cleft: This refers to the superior part of the nasal cavity where the olfactory epithelium is located, between the upper part of the septum and superior turbinate. It has no relation to the bulla ethmoidalis or uncinate process.

 

Option C. Frontonasal duct: This is an incorrect term that was historically used to describe the drainage pathway from the frontal sinus. No true duct exists; rather, the frontal sinus drains through the frontal recess into the middle meatus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The hiatus semilunaris is a critical landmark in the ostiomeatal complex, serving as an important reference point during endoscopic sinus surgery and forming part of the pathway for drainage of the anterior group of paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following is a manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bitot's spots

 

Bitot's spots are a characteristic manifestation of vitamin A deficiency. These are foamy, triangular, silvery-white spots that appear on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. They are composed of keratin debris and are a sign of xerophthalmia (dry eye) associated with vitamin A deficiency. Bitot's spots are an important clinical sign used to diagnose vitamin A deficiency, especially in developing countries where this nutritional deficiency is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's striae: Incorrect. These are vertical lines seen in the cornea of patients with keratoconus, a progressive eye disease that causes thinning and bulging of the cornea. They are not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Arlt's line: Incorrect. This refers to a linear scar on the inner surface of the upper eyelid, typically seen in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It is not associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Horner tantra dots: Incorrect. This appears to be a misspelling of "Horner-Trantas dots," which are white, chalky accumulations of eosinophils and epithelial cells at the limbus (the border between the cornea and the sclera). They are commonly seen in patients with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, an allergic eye condition, and are not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot's spots are a characteristic ocular manifestation of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as foamy, silvery-white spots on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: A man comes to the OPD with complaints of sinusitis and breathing difficulty. He also gives a history of infertility for the past few years. On further examination, thoracic cavity organs were found to be on the opposite side. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome


Kartagener syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (a condition where the thoracic and abdominal organs are mirrored from their normal positions).

 

The underlying cause of Kartagener syndrome is a defect in the structure and function of cilia, which are hair-like structures that line the respiratory tract and other parts of the body. These cilia are responsible for moving mucus and other substances along the respiratory tract, as well as for ensuring proper placement of organs during embryonic development.

 

In this case, the patient's symptoms of sinusitis, breathing difficulties, and history of infertility, combined with the finding of situs inversus, strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome. The infertility is due to immotile sperm in males, which is also caused by defective cilia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: This condition typically presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, and chest tightness. It is not associated with situs inversus or infertility.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It is not associated with situs inversus, sinusitis, or bronchiectasis.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Although it can cause chronic cough and sinusitis, it is not associated with situs inversus or infertility. Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes are permanently widened, leading to frequent lung infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the presence of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, and infertility, all of which result from defective ciliary function.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

 

In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.

 

The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.

 

The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.

 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery: The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.

 

Option B. Ascending pharyngeal artery: It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Option D. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of the tonsils:

 

 

Arterial supply:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.

 

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

 

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

 

1. Primary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

 

2. Reactionary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.

 

3. Secondary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: Shoulder dystocia is defined as delay in delivery of shoulders after delivery of head by? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60 sec

 

Shoulder dystocia is technically defined as a delay in delivery of shoulders for more than 60 seconds after delivery of the head. 

 

Once the head is delivered and external rotation/restitution occurs, if the anterior shoulder doesn't deliver with gentle traction, maneuvers to relieve shoulder dystocia should be initiated immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Shoulder dystocia has two definitions:

 

  1. Technical: Delay in shoulder delivery >60 seconds after head delivery
  2. Practical: Need for additional maneuvers beyond gentle traction to deliver shoulders after head delivery
  3. Turtle Sign: Seen in Shoulder dystocia

questions.text: During femoral vein catheterization, local anesthesia administered just below the inguinal ligament primarily blocks which of the following nerves? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Genitofemoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Genitofemoral nerve is blocked when the local anesthetic is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization.

 

The genitofemoral nerve is a mixed nerve that arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves. It descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from the lateral border of the muscle. It then divides into two branches: The genital branch, which supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the mons pubis, labia majora or scrotum, and cremaster muscle in males.

 

The femoral branch, which passes laterally over the iliacus muscle and descends along the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle. It supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the femoral triangle and the upper anterior thigh.

 

In addition to its sensory functions, the genitofemoral nerve also provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle in males, which raises the testes towards the body in response to cold or other stimuli. Dysfunction of the genitofemoral nerve can lead to sensory loss or motor weakness in the areas it innervates.

 

 

During femoral vein catheterization, local anesthesia is typically administered in the area inferior to the inguinal ligament and close to the femoral pulse. Among the given options, the genitofemoral nerve is the one most likely to be anesthetized during this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is the largest branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the dorsal divisions of the ventral rami of the L2-L4 spinal nerves. It descends through the iliopsoas muscle and enters the femoral triangle, lateral to the femoral vessels. The femoral nerve primarily supplies muscles in the anterior compartment of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. While it is in close proximity to the femoral vein, it is not the primary nerve targeted during femoral vein catheterization.

 

Option C. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh: This nerve originates from the L2-L3 levels of the lumbar plexus. It travels inferiorly and exits the pelvis under the inguinal ligament, close to the anterior superior iliac spine, to supply the skin on the lateral aspect of the thigh. While it is near the inguinal ligament, its location is more lateral compared to the site of femoral vein catheterization, making it less likely to be affected.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve arises from the L1 level of the lumbar plexus. It travels through the inguinal canal and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the groin, mons pubis, and scrotum or labium majus. The course and distribution of this nerve make it less relevant for femoral vein catheterization, which occurs more medially and inferiorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1-L2 levels of the lumbar plexus. It descends on the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle and then splits into two branches: the genital and femoral branches. The femoral branch pierces the fascia lata to provide sensory innervation to a small area of skin over the femoral triangle. Given its anatomical location and course, this nerve is likely to be anesthetized during femoral vein catheterization.

questions.text: For OME, Myringotomy is done in which quadrant? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antero-inferior

 

Explanation:

 

In Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), myringotomy is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. This location is specifically chosen because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding important structures. The antero-inferior quadrant is the safest area to make an incision as it avoids damage to the ossicles and other vital middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antero-posterior: No such quadrant exists.

 

Option C. Postero-superior: This is the most dangerous quadrant for myringotomy as it contains the incus and stapes. Additionally, the chorda tympani nerve runs through this area, and facial nerve injury is a risk if the incision extends too deeply. This area is avoided for routine myringotomy.

 

Option D. Postero-inferior: Although this quadrant is relatively safe compared to the postero-superior quadrant, it is not the preferred site for myringotomy. The round window niche is located in the posterior part of the middle ear, and damage to this structure could potentially affect inner ear function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringotomy for OME is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding vital middle ear structures, ensuring both effectiveness and safety of the procedure.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: The structure highlighted in green corresponds to which vertebral level in the anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

questions.text:
Which of the provided statements about the muscle depicted in the image are true? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius
  2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius
  3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
  4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

Marked muscle in the image given is Rhomboid Major and minor.

 

 

1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. Both the rhomboideus major and minor muscles play a role in scapular retraction. This means they help pull the scapula (shoulder blade) toward the midline of the body, which is an action involved in retracting the scapula. The middle fibers of the trapezius muscle also contribute to scapular retraction.
     

2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. The Rhomboids retract the scapula superiorly and medially from the medial border of the scapula, this in turn assists in elevation of the scapula along with upper fibers of trapezius..
     

3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly:

 

  • True. When scapula is retracted and elevated along the medial border by rhomboids the glenoid cavity turns inferiorly (the socket of the shoulder joint).

     

Other Option:
 

4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly:

 

  • False. The primary action of the rhomboideus major and minor muscles is not to tilt the glenoid cavity superiorly. Their main functions involve scapular retraction and elevation, as discussed in statements 1 and 2. Tilted movement of the glenoid cavity superiorly is not a primary function associated with these muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rhomboid Major and Minor muscles are key players in scapular stabilization, involved in retraction, elevation, and downward rotation of the scapula, aligning the glenoid cavity in a position that supports optimal shoulder function.

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.

 

The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.

 

Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.

 

Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include:

 

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)

 

Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.

 

Option. C. 3: This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.

 

Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: Which ion primarily drives the depolarization phase of action potential in cardiac muscles? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Na+

 

Explanation:


The action potential in cardiac muscles is initiated by the rapid influx of sodium ions (Na+) during Phase 0, the phase of rapid depolarization. This sudden influx results from the opening of fast sodium channels, which causes a sharp rise in the membrane potential towards a positive value. This process is crucial for initiating the sequence of electrical events that lead to muscle contraction. Sodium's role is pivotal in setting the fast response of cardiac myocytes, which differentiates cardiac muscle action potential from those in other types of muscle cells.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. K+: While potassium ions (K+) play significant roles in the initial repolarization (Phase 1) and final repolarization (Phase 3) by exiting the cell, they do not initiate the action potential.
  • Option c. Ca+2: Calcium ions contribute mainly to the Plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac action potential by entering the cell through slow voltage-gated channels, sustaining the depolarization longer than in other muscle cells, but they are not the primary trigger.
  • Option d. Cl: Chloride ions have minimal direct involvement in the generation or progression of cardiac action potentials.

 

Educational objective:


The initiation of the action potential in cardiac muscle cells is primarily driven by the influx of Na+ ions during the rapid depolarization phase, critical for the subsequent phases of the cardiac cycle.

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

Other Options


Option A. Giardia lamblia: The stool examination usually reveals oval-shaped cysts or trophozoites. Giardia does not produce eggs, distinguishing it from helminthic infections.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs are typically oval-shaped and brown-colored. They have a distinct thick shell and are not barrel-shaped, which helps differentiate them from Trichuris trichiura eggs.

 

 

Option D. Ancylostoma duodenale:  The eggs are oval and thin-shelled, significantly different in appearance from the barrel-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is caused by deficiency of:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a characteristic feature of severe rickets, which is caused by vitamin D deficiency. In severe cases of rickets, profound vitamin D deficiency leads to significant hypocalcemia. This low calcium level can cause muscle spasms, including spasm of the larynx, resulting in laryngismus stridulus. The condition is characterized by sudden, brief episodes of stridor (high-pitched breathing sound) due to laryngeal spasm.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Incorrect. While vitamin A deficiency can cause various health issues, including night blindness and increased susceptibility to infections, it is not associated with laryngismus stridulus or rickets.

 

Option C. Vitamin K: Incorrect. Vitamin K deficiency primarily affects blood clotting and is not related to the development of rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Incorrect. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) causes problems with collagen formation, leading to issues like easy bruising and poor wound healing, but it does not cause rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a manifestation of severe rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency, resulting in hypocalcemia and laryngeal muscle spasms.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using the SCOFF protocol? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eating disorder

 

The SCOFF questionnaire seems highly effective as a screening instrument for detecting eating disorders.

 

SCOFF QUESTIONS

 

  1. Do you make yourself Sick because you feel uncomfortably full?
  2. Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
  3. Have you recently lost more than One stone in a 3-month period?
  4. Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?
  5. Would you say that Food dominates your life?

 

*One point for every “yes”; a score of ⩾2 indicates a likely case of anorexia nervosa or bulimia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mental health disorder: While eating disorders fall under the broad category of mental health, the SCOFF tool is specifically tailored to screen for eating disorders, not general psychiatric conditions.

 

Option B. Behavioural disorder: Eating disorders do involve maladaptive behaviors, but the SCOFF questionnaire is not a general behavioral disorder screening tool.

 

Option C. Sexual health disorder: The SCOFF protocol does not assess sexual health or disorders related to sexual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The SCOFF questionnaire is a validated and effective screening tool for detecting eating disorders like anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. A score of ≥2 suggests the need for further psychiatric assessment.

questions.text: Asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane is due to: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Gibbs Donan reaction

 

The asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane is primarily due to the Gibbs Donan effect. This effect arises from the semi-permeable nature of the cell membrane, which allows certain ions to pass while restricting others. Inside the cell, there are non-diffusible ions such as phosphates and proteins. These non-diffusible ions create an imbalance in the distribution of diffusible ions like potassium (K⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻). The presence of non-diffusible ions inside the cell results in the repulsion of chloride ions and influences the movement of potassium ions, leading to an asymmetrical distribution of ions across the cell membrane. This equilibrium state is referred to as the Gibbs Donan equilibrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-K with primary active transport: This refers to the sodium-potassium pump (Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase), which actively transports sodium and potassium ions across the cell membrane using energy from ATP. This pump is essential for maintaining the resting membrane potential (RMP) but does not directly contribute to the asymmetrical ion differentiation as it is an active process, not a passive one like the Gibbs Donan effect.

 

Option C. Na-Cl pump: There is no specific Na-Cl pump involved in the asymmetric distribution of ions. Sodium and chloride ions are transported through different mechanisms, but they do not directly relate to the asymmetrical distribution explained by the Gibbs Donan effect.

 

Option D. Nernst Equilibrium: The Nernst equation calculates the equilibrium potential for a particular ion based on its concentration gradient across the membrane. It helps determine the magnitude of the potential difference but does not explain the asymmetrical distribution of ions itself. The Nernst equilibrium describes a theoretical condition, not the mechanism behind the asymmetrical ion distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs Donan reaction explains the asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane due to the presence of non-diffusible ions and the semi-permeable nature of the membrane.

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

 

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Serotype-specific tests:

 

  • Microscopic agglutination test
  • Macroscopic agglutination test

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Widal test: Incorrect, the Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever, which involves testing for antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens but does not present with the same symptom profile as described.

 

Option C. Weil Felix reaction: Incorrect, this test is historically used for diagnosing rickettsial infections, which are caused by different organisms and have different clinical features.

 

Option D. Paul Bunnell test (monospot test): Incorrect, this test is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, characterized by symptoms like fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes but not typically associated with icterus or hematuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in patients presenting with symptoms like fever, jaundice, red eyes, and hematuria, as it accurately detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira, confirming the infection.

questions.text: What is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Edrophonium

 

Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is used in the Tensilon test to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis. In patients with myasthenia gravis, the symptoms will improve following administration of edrophonium. In contrast, symptoms will worsen in a cholinergic crisis, indicating that the problem is excessive acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obidoxime: Obidoxime is primarily used to treat organophosphate poisoning and is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Option C. Donepezil: Donepezil is a long-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer's disease and is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug used to treat a variety of conditions, including poisoning by organophosphates and other substances that produce a cholinergic crisis. However, it is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edrophonium is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis by temporarily increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving symptoms in myasthenia gravis and worsening them in a cholinergic crisis.

questions.text: In the presence of elevated ADH levels, which part of the renal tubule reabsorbs the most water? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Proximal tubule

 

Explanation: 

 

The proximal tubule reabsorbs the largest percentage of filtered water (60-70%) even in the presence of ADH (vasopressin). This represents obligatory H₂O reabsorption that occurs regardless of hormonal status. The Loop of Henle handles 10-15% of water reabsorption, while the distal tubule and collecting ducts account for the remaining reabsorption, which is regulated by ADH as facultative H₂O reabsorption.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Loop of Henle - Only reabsorbs 10-15% of filtered water, significantly less than the proximal tubule. Water reabsorption here occurs primarily in the descending limb due to the presence of aquaporin-1 channels.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Reabsorbs only 1-3% of water without ADH and up to 10-15% with ADH, still considerably less than the proximal tubule.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - While ADH has its most significant effect here (making it critical for concentrating urine), the absolute amount of water reabsorbed is less than in the proximal tubule. Approximately 14.7% total water reabsorption occurs in the collecting ducts (10% in cortical + 4.7% in medullary collecting ducts).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The proximal tubule performs the majority of water reabsorption (60-70%) through obligatory mechanisms independent of ADH, while ADH primarily regulates the facultative water reabsorption in the distal segments of the nephron.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the illustration, which displays a baby's skull, is pointing in the direction of the anterior fontanelle. Ventricular tapping is the term used to describe the process of removing CSF from the anterior fontanelle. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

 

Fontanelle tap/ Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

 

Infants who need urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle and no access to a VP shunt undergo a fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture. A butterfly needle is used to immediately puncture the infant's open fontanelle and enter the lateral ventricle in order to obtain CS samples, alleviate pressure, or insert a drain or catheter.

 

Procedure: A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

 

When performing a fontanelle tap, the following layers are pierced:

 

  • Scalp: This includes the skin and the underlying connective tissue of the scalp.
  • Membranous fontanelle: The actual fontanelle is a soft spot on a baby's head where the bones of the skull have not yet fused together. It's a membranous gap between the cranial bones.
  • Dura mater: The tough outermost membrane of the three layers of the meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • Arachnoid mater: A thin, wispy layer that lies underneath the dura mater.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): Once through the arachanoid mater, the needle enters the subarachnoid space where the CSF is located.

 

Note: The fontanelle tap bypasses the bony skull, which is why it's an accessible route in neonates and infants for procedures that require access to the CSF. However, as the child grows, these fontanelles close, and the method is no longer viable.

 

Educational Objective:
